Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed clause; nominal predicate with genitive marker ‘do’’
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To act foolishly or proudly, especially after gaining small success.
Usage Contexts: Daily speech, humor, sarcasm, youth culture
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from old Keningau Murut village tales mocking a rooster that crowed proudly after escaping a trap.
First Example Sentence: Oku ino’ mingampai nga’ tos’on nga’ do’ ratu po do’ minoguhup ku nga’ i kazo’.
Second Example Sentence: Kou no’ tos’on nga’ do’ ratu nga’ songou i milou miampai do’ boros.
Third Example Sentence: Nga’ i tawa, sinong nga’ tos’on nga’ do’ ratu po!

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To show patience and endurance through hardship.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to the patience needed when wrapping ‘kalupis’ (sticky rice rolls), symbolizing perseverance.
First Example Sentence: Ino’ monguhup nga’ tobon nga’ do’ kalupis nga’ ginawo do’ susah.
Second Example Sentence: Tokou no’ milou nga’ tobon nga’ do’ kalupis do’ ginawo po.
Third Example Sentence: Kou ino’ miampai nga’ tobon nga’ do’ kalupis, aiso nga’ songou.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To face shame or embarrassment publicly.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rooted in traditional performance settings where the ‘tawan’ (stage) was central to communal ridicule or praise.
First Example Sentence: Oku no’ omotol do’ tawan nga’ milou miampai do’ boros po.
Second Example Sentence: Kou ino’ omotol do’ tawan nga’ songou nga’ ginawo ku.
Third Example Sentence: Nga’ i pasar, i Maria no’ omotol do’ tawan po.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Clause with genitive particle; idiomatic predicate
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: One who is overly proud of minor achievements.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Draws on imagery of a young rooster (tanak) boasting after crowing once.
First Example Sentence: Kou no’ sinu nga’ mino’ tanak nga’ i boros po.
Second Example Sentence: Oku ino’ milou nga’ sinu nga’ mino’ tanak po nga’ i sumandak.
Third Example Sentence: Nga’ i pasar, tokou no’ misampai nga’ sinu nga’ mino’ tanak po.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To have great courage in difficult times.
Usage Contexts: Moral sayings, war stories, family honor
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to the heart (‘kopio’) of a warrior (‘kinorut’), celebrated in Murut oral traditions.
First Example Sentence: Oku ino’ milou nga’ togom kopio nga’ kinorut nga’ ginawo do’ susah.
Second Example Sentence: Kou no’ monguhup nga’ togom kopio nga’ kinorut po.
Third Example Sentence: Nga’ i perang, i tawa no’ milou nga’ togom kopio nga’ kinorut.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To have very high or unrealistic ambitions.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Reflects Murut cosmology linking ambition with the sky (‘langit’).
First Example Sentence: Kou ino’ mogit nga’ i langit nga’ ginawo do’ minongkol.
Second Example Sentence: Oku no’ milou nga’ mogit nga’ i langit po.
Third Example Sentence: Nga’ i kampung, i tanak no’ mogit nga’ i langit nga’ miampai.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To stay quiet or avoid conflict intentionally.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: ‘Awi’ (bamboo) bends with wind—symbol of peaceful restraint.
First Example Sentence: Oku ino’ nopongo nga’ do’ awi nga’ boros po.
Second Example Sentence: Kou no’ nopongo nga’ do’ awi nga’ ginawo do’ susah.
Third Example Sentence: Tokou ino’ nopongo nga’ do’ awi po nga’ i pasar.

Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from the sumbiling fish known for erratic swimming.
First Example Sentence: Kou no’ kino nga’ i sumbiling nga’ ginawo po.
Second Example Sentence: Oku ino’ milou nga’ kino nga’ i sumbiling po nga’ i kawan.
Third Example Sentence: Nga’ i pasar, i Maria no’ kino nga’ i sumbiling po.

Idiom (Keningau Murut): Moguhup nga’ i boros do’ kopio
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To speak from the heart sincerely.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: ‘Kopio’ (heart) symbolizes emotional sincerity in Murut belief.
First Example Sentence: Oku ino’ moguhup nga’ i boros do’ kopio nga’ ginawo po.
Second Example Sentence: Kou no’ moguhup nga’ i boros do’ kopio nga’ i tawa.
Third Example Sentence: Nga’ i boros ku, oku ino’ moguhup nga’ i boros do’ kopio po.

Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: To exaggerate or lie for attention.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Based on the ‘langkob’ (hornbill) known for loud calls without substance.
First Example Sentence: Kou no’ tos’on nga’ do’ langkob nga’ boros po nga’ i pasar.
Second Example Sentence: Oku ino’ milou nga’ tos’on nga’ do’ langkob nga’ i kawan.
Third Example Sentence: Nga’ i tawa, i sumandak no’ tos’on nga’ do’ langkob po.
